title: French Constitutional Council rejects large parts of controversial immigration law
summary: The highest constitutional authority partially or totally rejected 35 articles out of 86 in the restrictive law passed by President Emmanuel Macron's government, which the far right had described as an 'ideological victory.'

title: $7,000 to escape Gaza: How Palestinians fleeing to Egypt are extorted
summary: A network of brokers and travel agencies, linked to Egyptian intelligence services, sell permits to exit the Palestinian enclave at exorbitant prices.

title: Immigration to France on the rise, boosted by students, employees and refugees
summary: According to Interior Ministry data, more than 320,000 first-time residence permits were issued in 2023 to non-European immigrants; a figure up by 1.4% – and a new record. Meanwhile, 17,000 people were deported.

title: 'I feed you and it's killing me': French farmers on why they are blocking roads
summary: From Brittany to Alsace, from the north to the southwest, Le Monde's reporters met farmers who spoke of the same problems: low incomes for demanding and increasingly complex work, and above all, a loss of meaning and recognition.

title: Swedish defense minister: Both Europe and US need Russia to not win the war in Ukraine
summary: Pal Jonson believes a Russian victory would have drastic consequences for Europe's security. He is hopeful that his country will quickly join NATO following the Turkish parliament's favorable vote.

title: Economist Hélène Périvier: To boost fertility, 'we need to take advantage of several public policies'
summary: In an interview, the expert in social and family policy evaluation says that the parental leave policy recently announced by Emmanuel Macron is insufficient by itself to boost France's birth rate.

title: Turkey finalizes Sweden's NATO accession
summary: Turkey's government newspaper on Thursday published a protocol on Sweden's accession to NATO, a final technical step in Ankara's ratification of the Nordic nation's bid to join the US-led alliance.

title: NASA announces end of historic Mars mission
summary: The American space agency announced Thursday that its Ingenuity helicopter can no longer fly due to rotor blade damage, bringing its three-year mission to a close.

title: Suez Canal traffic has dropped 42% since Houthi attacks, according to UN
summary: According to the UN Conference on Trade and Development, more than 20% of the world's container trade goes through the Suez Canal.

title: Narendra Modi, Macron's coveted yet embarrassing ally
summary: The French president will be visiting India on January 25 and 26. He will be the Indian prime minister's guest of honor on Republic Day.

title: French court acquits policeman who called sexual assault victim a 'whore'
summary: In a voicemail message mistakenly left on the plaintiff's answering machine, the police officer had repeatedly called her a 'whore.' The court ruled that these remarks did not constitute sexist insults.

title: US regulator FTC launches probe into AI investments by tech giants
summary: The FTC's inquiry, targeting investments made by Microsoft, Google and Amazon into generative AI startups OpenAI and Anthropic, is part of efforts by regulators to make sure they can keep up with progress in AI tech.

title: War in Ukraine: Questions remain after Russian military plane crash
summary: According to Moscow, the plane that crashed on Wednesday was carrying Ukrainian prisoners. However, the Ukrainian armed forces are convinced that the plane was delivering ammunition and missiles to Russian forces on the front line.

title: French farmers' protests: Two unions call for Paris blockade
summary: The Paris region branches for two of France's largest farmers' unions called to block access to the capital starting on Friday. Earlier Thursday, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal held a crisis meeting.

title: Russian woman sentenced to 27 years for killing anti-Ukraine blogger
summary: Darya Trepova, 26, was arrested on charges of killing hardline military blogger Vladen Tatarsky in an explosion. She has claimed to have been 'set up,' but the court sentenced her to a prison colony on terrorism charges.

title: Posy Simmonds wins Grand Prix at Angoulême Comics Festival
summary: The author of graphic novels 'Gemma Bovery' and 'Tamara Drewe' is the first British winner of the top prize at this festival, whose 51st edition runs from January 25 to 28.

title: French Assemblée votes in favor of making abortion a constitutional 'guaranteed freedom'
summary: The bill was passed by 99 votes to 13, after nearly eight hours of sometimes heated debate. A solemn vote is scheduled for January 30 in the Assemblée Nationale, before the Sénat considers the bill at the end of February.

title: French farmers' protests: Map of the main roadblocks
summary: The mobilization against rising costs and excessive regulations started in Southwestern France and is gradually spreading to other regions.

title: 'It's hard to fail. But it's worse never to have tried to succeed': Should we put an end to inspirational office quotes?
summary: Once exclusive to startups, motivational quotes from figures like Gandhi, Churchill or Steve Jobs are now widespread across corporate walls. Intended to motivate staff, they can sometimes have the opposite effect.

title: 'Donald Trump glosses over his diplomatic legacy in the Middle East, where his results now appear highly questionable'
summary: In criticizing Joe Biden's foreign policy, the former president overlooks the impasses in Iran and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict that he passed on to his successor, says Gilles Paris.

title: Alabama carries out first US execution using nitrogen gas
summary: The US state of Alabama on Thursday executed Kenneth Eugene Smith, who was sentenced to death in 1996 for a 1988 murder, using the controversial method the UN has likened to 'torture.'

title: Is Nelson Mandela's legacy for sale?
summary: The auction of personal items belonging to the former president, provided by one of his daughters, has angered some of his family and the South African government, who cite heritage concerns.

title: Gérard Depardieu in North Korea: The preposterous making of a profane documentary
summary: On December 7, 2023, a French TV program aired excerpts from a documentary shot in 2018 in North Korea, in which Gérard Depardieu makes obscene remarks about women. The never-released film by the writer Yann Moix sparked a legal battle and led to the downfall of an idol.

title: French immigration law: Constitutional Council rejects measures largely on procedural grounds
summary: In their Thursday ruling, the nine members of the highest constitutional authority dismissed 32 out of 86 articles adopted by Parliament over procedural concerns. They partially or wholly rejected three articles as being substantively anticonstitutional.

title: Sinner ends Djokovic streak in Australia Open semi-final upset
summary: Ten-time champion Novak Djokovic had not tasted defeat at the Australian Open since 2018, but Jannik Sinner bested him 6-1, 6-2, 6-7 (6), 6-3.

title: 'French mercenaries' killed in Ukraine: Paris calls out a Russian disinformation operation
summary: On Wednesday, January 17, Moscow claimed to have killed around 60 foreign fighters operating on French payroll in a strike on a building in Kharkiv, eastern Ukraine.

title: 'A Nice Jewish Boy': The French film that accidentally anticipated a rise in anti-Semitism
summary: Writer-director Noé Debré considered delaying the release of his debut feature film based on the life of a young Jewish man in the Paris suburbs due to the response in France to the Israel-Hamas war.

title: Monaco: The princely family's financial secrets revealed
summary: 'Monaco: The secret notebooks' (Part 1/4): Le Monde delves into the notes of Claude Palmero, Prince Albert's former estate administrator who held that position for more than 20 years, until his ousting in 2023. His five notebooks make for explosive reading.

title: French farmers eye Paris blockade as government looks to quell protests
summary: Farmers around France have organized to hold out for as long as it takes against what they see as the growing complexity of the norms they must respect.

title: Monaco: When the time comes to settle accounts
summary: 'Monaco: The secret notebooks' (4/4). By dismissing Claude Palmero, his former éminence grise, in June 2023, Prince Albert II risked publicly exposing the handling of his family's assets. The conflict between the two men could have unfortunate political and fiscal consequences for the Principality.

title: LVMH makes record sales, despite slowdown in luxury goods market
summary: The world's number one luxury goods company reported a growth of 9% in 2023, reaching a turnover of €86.2 billion and net profits of €15.2 billion.

title: AFCON 2024: Village of witch doctors blamed for Côte d'Ivoire's misfortunes
summary: Following the national team's defeat by Equatorial Guinea, riots broke out in Akradio, a village home to witch doctors suspected of influencing the team's fate.

title: India celebrates France's Macron at annual military parade
summary: President Emmanuel Macron was guest of honor at a parade showcasing the country's military power and cultural heritage to mark its 75th Republic Day.

title: Motaz Azaiza: Palestinian reporter who became Instagram celebrity leaves Gaza
summary: The young self-taught journalist has flown to Qatar after covering the devastation caused by Israeli bombing for over three months.

title: Biden halts new US natural gas export facilities, citing climate
summary: The US president's administration said new liquified natural gas (LNG) export applications would be subjected to an indefinite review considering climate and wider environmental and economic impacts

title: Machu Picchu protesters block tourist train tracks over privatizing ticket sales
summary: Local operators are fighting the 'systematic privatization' of the historic site, but the culture ministry claim this move is necessary to control visitor numbers.

title: 'After the Hamas attack on Israel, militias have become major players in the Middle East'
summary: Iran is the master of the militia spider's web and, whether their actions are coordinated or not, they are having an impact on the whole region, writes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

title: Jurgen Klopp announces he's standing down as Liverpool manager at end of season
summary: Klopp revealed his shock decision to leave the Premier League club on Friday, saying he was 'running out of energy.'

title: Russia extends pre-trial detention of US journalist by two months
summary: Evan Gershkovich was arrested last March on charges of 'collecting information constituting a state secret about the activities of one of the enterprises of the Russian military-industrial complex.'

title: King Charles arrives in hospital for prostate surgery
summary: In a break with former secrecy about royals' health, the Palace revealed last week that the 75-year-old monarch would have a 'corrective procedure' for an enlarged prostate.
